quizItems.text: We have established sustainability goals for the event
We have developed a roadmap for long term sustainability planning
We have created goals to guide our sustainability journey
We set clear goals at all levels of the organization and define stakeholder responsibilities and success criteria
We have a team (individual) dedicated to sustaianbility
We measure and evalute sustaianbility initiatives internally
We use third-party monitoring tools to track and improve sustainability efforts
We have an inclusion policy for our event
We provide basic inclusion training to staff and gather informal feedback from participants
We provide structured inclusion training, track progress with monitoring tools, and collect regular stakeholder feedback to improve the policy
All stakeholders have been notified of their resposibilities regarding sustaianbility
We include at least one open-access activity (e.g., a public talk or showcase) during the event
We organize interactive workshops or sessions that are free and open to the public
We co-create part of the event program with community members and ensure multiple sessions are inclusive, free, and publicly accessible
We organize workshops or learning methods to educate the audience about reusability, durability, and recyclability
We collaborate with municipality to research and implement new sustainability solutions
We collaborate with universities to research and implement new sustaianbility solutions
We promote an existing awareness campaign (e.g., #ReFashionNow) through our social media channels and event materials
We integrate awareness campaigns into the event with interactive elements like posters, QR codes, or short talks to engage attendees
We create or co-host a branded awareness campaign (e.g., #ReFashionNow) with external partners or influencers to increase reach and impact
We require vendors and partners to align with our zero-waste principles (e.g., no plastic packaging, reusable materials)
We have a clear procurement policy that excludes items/services not supporting our zero-waste goals and monitor compliance through supplier agreements.
We make a donation plan to donate or repurpose/reuse leftover materials after the event.
We have a list of partners or organizations that can reuse or recycle event materials, and we coordinate with them post-event.
We implement a structured post-event materials strategy with tracking, evaluation, and reporting on reuse, redistribution, and waste minimization.
We provided attendees with a simple digital guide outlining basic sustainability practices
We shared a detailed guide with specific recommendations for low-carbon travel, food, and behavior, sent before the event and available on-site

We provided personalized best-practice tips and lowest-carbon options based on attendee location or registration data (e.g., recommending train over plane), and ensured accessibility via app or onboarding system
At least 25% of the event infrastructure is powered by renewable energy sources (e.g., green energy, HVO)
At least 50% of the event infrastructure is powered by renewable energy sources
100% of the event infrastructure is powered by renewable energy sources
We use batteries and/or hydrogen generators as alternative power sources for the event
All batteries used in the event are rechargeable and have a low-toxicity battery system
We have initiated or established collaboration with local municipalities to explore alternative energy solutions
We have incorporated municipal or regional renewable energy infrastructure (e.g., blue energy, battery systems) into the event's energy plan
We have conducted research into alternative energy solutions for events and identified potential opportunities for municipal collaboration
We have critically assessed the event’s energy needs and optimized usage by considering time of day, natural lighting, and necessary equipment only
We have set energy limits on locations to optimise power usage - provide link how to do
We ensure all lights are off when rooms are empty
We reduce/turn off outdoor lights when areas are not in use
We require that all electronic equipment used at the event complies with the EU Energy Label standards (A to G rating system) - LINK ZA OVO
All vending machines present at the event have built-in energy-saving systems (e.g., LED lighting, smart cooling, standby modes)
Show-specific installations are designed to be reused or repurposed for future events or other uses
All newly purchased technical equipment has documented energy efficiency certification (e.g., EU Energy Label, Energy Star)

Unused but working electronics are donated through a recognized reuse or refurbishment program certified by national or international e-waste standards (e.g., Wecycle NL, Reuse Network UK, e-Stewards USA)
Clear behavioral signage is displayed at the event (e.g., “Please take only one,” “Shut off the water,” “Turn off lights when not in use”) to encourage responsible resource use
We provide visitors with a map or list of public transport options and bike routes to the event location
We partner with Mobility-as-a-Service (MaaS) platforms to offer integrated travel planning tools (e.g., app or website access) that suggest green transport routes and booking options to attendees
All attendees of the event have received best practices, optimized routes, impact of the routes and the lowest carbon option in terms of transportation
We provide coordinated group transport options for both attendees and event staff/models/performers
We organize and promote group transportation that includes attendees, staff, and contributors, using low-emission vehicles (e.g., electric buses, shared EVs)
We provide financial support for sustaianble travel to the event through grants or reimbursement program
We include a fixed Solidarity Eco Tax on all ticket purchases to contribute to offsetting event-related travel emissions
We calculate and apply a variable Solidarity Eco Tax based on the estimated travel distance of each ticket buyer to reflect their individual carbon footprint
We request that delivery providers disclose vehicle emission standards and prioritize lower-emission options when available
We contract only with delivery providers who use Euro 6 (or equivalent) low-emission certified vehicles for event logistics
We ensure that all delivery trucks used for the event are electric, hybrid, or certified zero-emissions vehicles
We ensure that all logistic vans used for the event meet ECO standards (Euro 5 or higher)
We identify opportunities to bundle deliveries from the same supplier or internal departments into one combined shipment
We actively collaborate with multiple suppliers to bundle their deliveries into fewer, combined venue shipments
We have implemented a centralized logistics system or hub that bundles and delivers all event materials in a single, optimized package to the venue
We use hydrotreated vegetable oil (HVO) for on site transport instead of traditional fuels
We requested caterers to minimize trips and consolidate deliveries wherever possible
If caterers cannot optimize deliveries, the event team coordinates delivery schedules to reduce fuel use and emissions
The venue uses water-efficient fixtures (e.g., low-flow taps or toilets) in restrooms and kitchens
The venue implements basic greywater reuse (e.g., water from sinks reused for flushing toilets or irrigation)
The venue has an integrated water reuse system (e.g., rainwater harvesting, full greywater recycling, or filtration systems used for multiple event needs)
We utilize the venue’s existing water infrastructure and avoid installing temporary water systems for the event
The venue was chosen and scheduled to use natural light to lower energy spending
Only certified sustainable soaps, detergents, and cleaning products were used prior, during, and after the event
All paper and cleaning supplies at the event meet EU Ecolabel requirements
The kitchen team has a documented plan for meal planning, storage, and minimizing food waste, including communication with guests when needed
The event is hosted at a venue that monitors and reports its carbon emissions, providing accessible data to support sustainability tracking
We offer parking for bikes and cars
All our suppliers comply with ethical, sustainable and animal walfare standards
At least 30% of the food ingredients used by providers are certified organic
At least 60% of the food ingredients used by providers are certified organic, with a focus on fresh produce and dairy.
100% of the food ingredients used by all food providers are certified organic.
All food vendors are sourced from within a 100 km radius of the event location - GPP says this is local
All oils used are certified sustainable (e.g., EU Organic, RSPO)
endagared and unsustainable seafood options are banned from menues
We provide vegan, vegetarian and gluten free optins to everyone that is part of the event in any way
The event discloses plant protein infromation for meals
We Encourage local restaurants to adopt sustainable menus for festival attendees
Caterers and venues have been informed about food waste prevention practices by the organizers
Caterers and venues have received guidance from organizers on how to redistribute food surplus.
Organizers have communicated waste management procedures to caterers and venues.
Organizers have shared key environmental indicators with caterers and venues to support sustainable operations.
The food providors of the event are using a multi day ingrediant re use system to cut down food waste
We have implemented at least one strategy to reduce future food waste (e.g., portion control, adjusted ordering, real-time tracking).
We analyze food waste data to identify key sources of waste and adjust planning accordingly.
We have a system in place to measure and log all food waste generated during the event.
We have made arrangements to return unopened or unused goods (e.g., drinks) to the retailer/ distributor after the event.
We have a plan in place to manage leftover food in order to prevent food waste (e.g., redistribution, donation, staff meals).
Caterers hired for the event track and report their sustainability practices at least twice per year.
All cutlery, dishes, and drinkware are reusable, and If disposables are used, they are biodegradable or recyclable
All food packaging used at the event is compostable, recyclable, or made from certified bio-based materials
Reusable hard cups are used insted of single used plastics or disposables to decrease overall aste
Tap water is made available at key locations during the event (e.g., refill stations, catering points)
Bottled water is limited to staff and emergency use only; attendees are encouraged to bring reusable bottles.
Bottled water is completely eliminated; free branded reusable bottles and widely accessible refill stations are provided
All workers involved in the event are paid at or above the local living wage standard - find source with the world minimal age infromatin
All workers are provided with clear employment terms and dismissal procedures
All staff and freelancers are provided with clear, fair contracts
All staff and crew are provided with scheduled breaks in accordance with national labor laws and regulations
The event complies with the 20 principles of the European Pillar of Social Rights - provide link
We have taken intentional steps to make our recruitment and collaboration inclusive (e.g., sharing opportunities with diverse networks or platforms).
Several staff or crew members are hired locally to support the event across different roles (e.g., logistics, setup, coordination)
Equal opportunity and pay policy is in place and applied across all event roles, ensuring no gender-based discrimination in hiring, responsibilities, or compensation.

A resource allocation plan has been created that outlines how equipment, workspace, and budget are distributed across departments or roles, and it has been reviewed to ensure equity (e.g., similar roles have access to similar tools and support)
The event includes models and participants representing a diverse range of body types, genders, and physical abilities, as evidenced in casting decisions, show lineups, and visual materials.

The event creatively integrates all team roles (e.g., catering staff, backstage crew) into the experience, such as involving them in fashion styling or thematic presentations to promote inclusion and sustainability through innovative formats
Our event complies with health and safety standards for all workspaces and staff
The event provides on-site access to first aid, visible health and safety information, and a documented emergency response plan available to all staff and attendees
Quiet spaces are arranged backstage to support staff and talent well-being, including designated areas for rest or decompression
Backstage staff and volunteers have received trauma-informed training to ensure a safe and supportive environment for all participants
We have identified whether any staff or crew have childcare needs and adjusted schedules or provided relevant support accordingly
We provide internships or upskilling opportunities through our event
All staff and volunteers have participated in a training session or received materials on sustainability and circular practices relevant to their role
Local community members are engaged in the event through at least one of the following: paid positions, training programs, volunteer opportunities, or long-term partnerships.
Local second-hand or vintage stores are promoted or included in the event (e.g., via pop-up stalls, partnerships, or mentions in communications)
All supply chain partners, including the venue and their subcontractors (e.g., vendors, suppliers), have been informed about and agree to adhere to the event’s sustainability requirements
All fabrics used for event decoration or staging are sourced from nature-based and ethically responsible suppliers
The organization actively participates in government-led sustainability initiatives or working groups to contribute to shaping relevant policies
The organization is an active member of an industry-wide sustainability initiative (e.g., fashion councils, alliances, or networks)
Recycling stations are available at the venue for all five mandatory waste streams (plastic, paper, glass, metal, textiles), or the event organizers ensure their setup.
The event partners with local recycling facilities to ensure proper sorting, collection, and processing of event waste
We have a plan in place for the leftover food
The event has partnered with a certified composting service to process organic waste generated during the event.
Leftover meals are offered to event staff before expiration and food safety protocols are followed
We use meal-planning technology to avoid overproduction
We enable "pay What you can" booths at the end of the day for surplus food
We trach surplus quantities of food leftover for smarter planning for the next event
